metadata.titleEn: Geochemical data set of the Paleocene-Eocene  thermal maximum at Gamba and Tingri, southern Tibet
metadata.description: This data set comes from shallow marine carbonate sections at Tingri and Gamba, south Tibet. The age of these samples is about 56 Ma (at the Paleocene-Eocene boundary). At Tingri, we studied two parallel sections (13ZS section and 10-11TM section), and at Gamba, we studied one section (11TMG). From the 13ZS section, we analyzed carbon and oxygen isotopic compositions and calcium carbonate content of the whole carbonate rock, as well as the in-situ carbon isotopic compositions and element contents of the foraminifera shell. From the 10-11TM section, we analyzed carbon, oxygen and strontium isotopic compositions of the whole rock. From the 11TMG section, we analyzed carbon and oxygen isotopic compositions of the whole carbonate rock. Carbon and oxygen isotopic compositions of the whole rock were measured by gas isotope mass spectrometer (MAT251), strontium isotope by thermal ionization mass spectrometry (TIMS), calcium carbonate content by acid dissolution, in-situ carbon isotopic compositions by SIMS, and in-situ element contents by LA-ICPMS. Among these data, in-situ carbon isotope data were obtained from the laboratory of Professor John Valley at the University of Wisconsin-Madison in the United States, and the rest are from the relevant laboratories of the Department of Geosciences at the University of Bremen in Germany. Based on these data, we published three peer-reviewed papers on Journals of Gondwana Research, GSA Bulletin, and Global and Planetary Change.

background: The Paleocene-Eocene thermal maximum (PETM) is one of the most pronounced global warming events in the Cenozoic. This event was associated with a large negative carbon isotope excursion (CIE) and with major changes in the atmosphere, hydrosphere, and biosphere. About 56 m.y. ago, global temperature rose rapidly by at least 4–5 °C, and this temperature anomaly persisted for ~170 k.y. This event, now called the Paleocene-Eocene thermal maximum (PETM), was associated with severe carbonate dissolution on the deep-sea floor and with a ~2–7‰ negative carbon isotope excursion (CIE), indicating a massive addition of 13 C-depleted carbon into the atmosphere-ocean system. The CIE was documented by diverse substrates from different depositional environments, ranging from paleosol carbonate, tooth enamel, plant lipids, soil organic matter on land to foraminifera, bulk carbonate, and marine organic matter in the ocean. Therefore, the CIE reflects a global geochemical event, and not a regional carbon perturbation. Along with the PETM-CIE, dramatic changes took place in the ocean-atmosphere system, such as a marked increase in atmospheric CO2 concentration, intensified seasonal precipitation and weathering, abrupt reversal of deep-ocean circulation, rapid ocean acidification, and increased ocean stratification. In different ecosystems, fauna and flora showed variable responses to this warming event. On land, insect herbivory increased sharply as floral composition changed from mixed gymnosperms and angiosperms prior to the PETM to almost exclusively angiosperms during the PETM. Many mammals became smaller, and migrated from Asia to North America. In the tropical surface ocean, reef-building corals retreated to middle latitudes, planktonic foraminifera diversified rapidly, and calcareous nannoplankton experienced increased rates of origination and extinction. In the deep ocean, smaller benthic foraminifera suffered one of the largest extinctions in the Cenozoic with the loss of ~30%–50% species. Despite substantial progress in the PETM studies, how larger benthic foraminifera (LBFs) in the shallow Tethyan Ocean responded to the PETM is still debated.
research objective: In this study, we investigate two shallow-marine, LBF-rich carbonate sections from south Tibet, aiming to locate the position of the Paleocene/Eocene (P/E) boundary in the Tethyan shallow benthic zones (SBZs) and to examine the response of the LBFs to the PETM. In summary, we construct a LBF biostratigraphy, pinpoint the P/E boundary in the SBZs, and discuss the LBF response to the PETM.
challenges: Unfortunately, it appears that some studied sections from Spain and Egypt do not meet these requirements, because they either comprise non-marine sediments or contain reworked LBFs in the stratigraphic interval close to the P/E boundary. Thus, even for some fully marine carbonate sections with in situ LBFs, whether these sections are “complete” on millennial time scales and have preserved carbonate sediments produced in this geologically brief time interval is also vital to the precise designation of the P/E boundary and to understanding of the LBF response to the PETM.
methods: In this study, we logged section 13ZS at Tingri (N28°41 ′35 ″, E86°42 ′32 ″) and section 11TMG at Gamba (N28°17 ′01 ″, E88°31 ′47 ″). For δ13 C and δ18 O analyses, samples were cut to expose their fresh surfaces. On their fresh surfaces, diagenetically less-altered micrites and LBF fragments were carefully micro-drilled under a light microscope. About 20 g of material was obtained from each sample and then ground to powder in an agate mortar. For δ13 C and δ18 O measurements, ~100 µg of rock powder were reacted with phosphoric acid at 75 °C in an automated carbonate unit. The isotopic composition (δ13 C, δ18 O) of the resulting CO2 was measured with a Finnigan MAT 251 gas isotope ratio mass spectrometer at the MARUM, University of Bremen.
findings: The combination of the carbon isotope data and constructed SBZs shows that the P/E boundary is located within SBZ5, not at the SBZ4/SBZ5 transition as proposed in the Western Tethyan domain. At the P/E boundary, no evident compositional change in LBF assemblages can be observed. However, a major compositional change in LBF assemblages occurs in the CIE recovery, characterized by the sudden disappearance of Miscellanea, Ranikothalia, Setia, Orbitosiphon, and the initial dominance of porcellaneous-walled Alveolina and Orbitolites together with small miliolids and rotaliids.

background: The Paleocene-Eocene Thermal Maximum (PETM) was a geologically rapid and transient warming event that occurred ca. 56 million years ago (Ma). It was associated with a pronounced negative carbon isotope excursion (CIE) and with profound changes in the atmosphere, hydrosphere and biosphere. A geologically rapid event characterized by profound changes in biotic evolution, climate and geochemical cycling occurred at the Paleocene-Eocene transition. During this event, now called the Paleocene-Eocene Thermal Maximum (PETM), global temperature increased by N4° C within several thousand years. This warming event was accompanied by a global negative CIE of ~2–8‰ and severe carbonate dissolution on the ocean floor. The combination of the CIE and carbonate dissolution indicates that a large amount of 13C–depleted carbon was injected into the atmosphere-ocean system.
research objective: In this study, we present the first records of carbon isotope composition of bulk carbonate (δ13C_carb) and wt% CaCO3 (weight percentage) from two parallel limestone sections (13ZS and 10/11TM) at Tingri (south Tibet), and the δ13C_carb data show that an expanded CIE profile is preserved in this area. Then, we use data of Sr and Mn concentrations and 87Sr/86Sr ratios to exclude the possibility of diagenetic alteration. By comparing the background δ13C_carb values at Tingri with the background δ13C values of mixed-layer foraminifer Acarinina from different ODP Sites, we confirm that the δ13C_carb records from the shallow epicontinental sea of the Tingri area can reflect the carbon cycling in the open surface ocean. In the end, we discuss the stepped CIE profile and the CIE magnitude during the PETM.
challenges: Although ODP Site 690 was regarded as the reference section for the PETM, the validity of the stepped CIE profile recorded in its bulk carbonate has been called into question, on the basis of two lines of evidence: (1) the δ13C measurements of both planktonic and benthic foraminifera from the same section cannot reproduce the stepped CIE profile, and (2) the stepped CIE profile was thought to be caused by vital effects of nannoplankton. The issue about the primary nature of the stepped CIE remains unresolved, because an expanded, high-resolution stepped CIE profile has not been observed so far.
methods: Here, we present carbon isotope data of bulk carbonate from two parallel limestone sections at Tingri (south Tibet), where the limestone was deposited on a tropical carbonate ramp during the PETM.
dataset: Carbon isotope data of bulk carbonate from both sections are almost identical, displaying an expanded stepped CIE profile with large magnitude. The stepped CIE profile consists of three discrete intervals of decreasing carbon isotope values, which can be correlated on an inter-regional scale between sections from different depositional environments (lake, carbonate ramp, continental slope, and open ocean).
findings: The consistency of these correlations implies occurrence of at least three carbon releases within the CIE and indicates complex processes of carbon injection during the PETM. Moreover, the CIE magnitude of ~7‰ recorded at Tingri is tentatively interpreted to reflect carbon isotope changes in the atmosphere and the surface ocean, which is larger than the generally accepted value of ~4‰ but is still within the range of some previous records.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to obtain carbon isotope data in paleoclimatology studies?
Example.Answer: In the field of paleoclimatology, carbon isotope data can be collected using gas isotope ratio mass spectrometry. For instance, in analyses, samples are cut to expose fresh surfaces, and micrites and foraminifera fragments are micro-drilled to obtain material. The isotopic composition (δ13C, δ18O) of the resulting CO2 from the reaction with phosphoric acid is measured using a gas isotope ratio mass spectrometer such as the Finnigan MAT 251.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced when trying to determine the completeness of marine carbonate sections for identifying the Paleocene/Eocene boundary?
Example.Answer: A challenge in determining the completeness of marine carbonate sections is ensuring that sections are complete on millennial time scales and have preserved carbonate sediments produced in the geologically brief interval of the Paleocene/Eocene boundary. Some sections, like those from Spain and Egypt, contain either non-marine sediments or reworked foraminifera, complicating the precise designation of the boundary.

Definition.Question: What is the significance of 'strontium isotope ratios' in geological studies?
Definition.Answer: Strontium isotope ratios, specifically the 87Sr/86Sr ratio, are used in geological studies to assess the diagenetic alteration of carbonate rocks. These ratios can help determine whether the isotopic composition of the rocks has been affected by post-depositional processes, thus ensuring the reliability of the isotopic data for interpreting past environmental and climatic conditions.

Definition.Question: What does the term 'shallow benthic zones (SBZs)' refer to in the context of biostratigraphy?
Definition.Answer: Shallow benthic zones (SBZs) refer to specific ecological zones in shallow marine environments that are characterized by the presence of certain types of benthic organisms, such as larger benthic foraminifera (LBFs). These zones are used in biostratigraphy to delineate time intervals and correlate sedimentary layers across different geographic areas, aiding in the identification of geological boundaries like the Paleocene/Eocene boundary.

Comparison.Question: How do the methods used to analyze carbon and oxygen isotopes in carbonate rock samples from the Tingri and Gamba sections compare in terms of their precision and potential sources of error?
Comparison.Answer: The carbon and oxygen isotopes in the carbonate rock samples from the Tingri and Gamba sections were analyzed using gas isotope ratio mass spectrometry (MAT251) at the University of Bremen, with careful micro-drilling to obtain diagenetically less-altered micrites and LBF fragments. Potential sources of error could include the selection of sample sites and the precision of the micro-drilling technique, which are critical for ensuring that the least altered samples are analyzed.

Comparison.Question: What are the similarities and differences in the challenges faced when identifying the Paleocene/Eocene boundary in the shallow Tethyan Ocean compared to other regions like Spain and Egypt?
Comparison.Answer: In the shallow Tethyan Ocean, identifying the Paleocene/Eocene boundary involves constructing a biostratigraphy and examining the response of larger benthic foraminifera (LBFs), with challenges including the preservation of carbonate sediments and the completeness of the sections on millennial time scales. In contrast, some sections from Spain and Egypt face challenges due to non-marine sediments or reworked LBFs, which complicate precise boundary designation.

Interpretation.Question: What can be inferred about the effectiveness and limitations of using carbon isotope excursions (CIE) in interpreting ancient global warming events from geochemical data?
Interpretation.Answer: The carbon isotope excursions (CIE) are used to indicate massive additions of 13C-depleted carbon into the atmosphere-ocean system, reflecting a global geochemical event. The CIE is documented in diverse substrates and environments, suggesting its reliability in indicating global changes. However, challenges remain in ensuring the completeness of carbonate sections on millennial time scales, which is crucial for precise boundary designations and interpretations of organism responses to the event.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes variations in carbon isotope data from different depositional environments when studying the Paleocene-Eocene thermal maximum?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The carbon isotope data from different depositional environments, such as lake, carbonate ramp, continental slope, and open ocean, show variations due to the complex processes of carbon injection during the Paleocene-Eocene thermal maximum (PETM). The expanded stepped carbon isotope excursion (CIE) profile, consisting of three discrete intervals, suggests multiple carbon releases and indicates complex carbon cycling in these environments.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why might some sections studied in other regions fail to provide complete records of the Paleocene/Eocene boundary?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Some sections from regions like Spain and Egypt may not provide complete records of the Paleocene/Eocene boundary due to the presence of non-marine sediments or reworked larger benthic foraminifera (LBFs) near the boundary. Additionally, even fully marine sections might lack completeness on millennial time scales or fail to preserve carbonate sediments produced during this brief geological interval, impacting the precision of boundary designation and understanding of LBF response.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What are the causes behind the challenges in identifying the primary nature of the stepped carbon isotope excursion profile during the PETM?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The challenges in identifying the primary nature of the stepped carbon isotope excursion (CIE) profile are caused by discrepancies in δ13C measurements from planktonic and benthic foraminifera, which do not reproduce the stepped profile observed in bulk carbonate. Additionally, vital effects of nannoplankton are thought to cause the stepped profile, raising questions about its authenticity and necessitating further exploration for a high-resolution, expanded profile.

Causal Consequence.Question: What happens when geochemical data from shallow-marine carbonate sections are used to interpret the Paleocene-Eocene thermal maximum event?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The use of geochemical data from shallow-marine carbonate sections, such as carbon isotope composition and carbonate content, allows for the identification of the Paleocene/Eocene boundary and the carbon isotope excursion (CIE) profile, providing insights into carbon cycling and climate changes during the PETM.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of identifying incomplete stratigraphic sections on the interpretation of the Paleocene-Eocene boundary?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Identifying incomplete stratigraphic sections may lead to challenges in precisely designating the Paleocene/Eocene boundary and understanding the response of larger benthic foraminifera to the PETM, potentially affecting the reconstruction of biostratigraphy and interpretation of large-scale environmental changes during this period.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the goals of analyzing the carbon and oxygen isotope composition in carbonate rocks within the context of the Paleocene-Eocene thermal maximum?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The analysis of carbon and oxygen isotope composition in carbonate rocks aims to understand the response of larger benthic foraminifera (LBFs) to the Paleocene-Eocene thermal maximum (PETM), locate the position of the Paleocene/Eocene boundary in the Tethyan shallow benthic zones (SBZs), and investigate the carbon cycling in the open surface ocean during this period.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to use isotopic and elemental analysis techniques like TIMS and LA-ICPMS for studying geochemical events related to the Paleocene-Eocene transition?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Using techniques such as TIMS and LA-ICPMS is important for ensuring the accuracy and reliability of isotopic and elemental data, which are critical for excluding diagenetic alteration and for identifying changes in carbon isotope composition that reflect global geochemical events like the Paleocene-Eocene thermal maximum (PETM).

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What specific procedures are involved in obtaining carbon isotope data from carbonate samples in the context of studying the Paleocene-Eocene thermal maximum?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: In the context of studying the Paleocene-Eocene thermal maximum, carbon isotope data from carbonate samples are obtained by cutting samples to expose fresh surfaces. Diagenetically less-altered micrites and larger benthic foraminifera fragments are carefully micro-drilled under a light microscope. Approximately 20 g of material is collected from each sample, ground into powder, and reacted with phosphoric acid at 75 °C. The isotopic composition of the resulting CO2 is measured using a Finnigan MAT 251 gas isotope ratio mass spectrometer.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the steps taken to ensure that the carbon isotope records from the Tingri area reflect carbon cycling in the open surface ocean, and how is diagenetic alteration ruled out?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To ensure that carbon isotope records from the Tingri area reflect carbon cycling in the open surface ocean, the study compares the background δ13C_carb values at Tingri with those of mixed-layer foraminifer Acarinina from different ODP Sites. Additionally, Sr and Mn concentrations and 87Sr/86Sr ratios are used to exclude the possibility of diagenetic alteration.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How is the carbon isotope data from bulk carbonate used to identify and analyze the expanded stepped CIE profile during the PETM?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Carbon isotope data from bulk carbonate are used to identify and analyze the expanded stepped CIE profile by examining two parallel limestone sections. The data reveal a stepped CIE profile consisting of three discrete intervals of decreasing carbon isotope values. These intervals are correlated on an inter-regional scale across different depositional environments, indicating multiple carbon releases during the PETM.

Enablement.Question: What technological methods are utilized to ensure the accuracy and integrity of geochemical data collected from carbonate sections during the Paleocene-Eocene thermal maximum?
Enablement.Answer: The accuracy and integrity of geochemical data are ensured through the use of gas isotope ratio mass spectrometry (MAT251) for carbon and oxygen isotopes, thermal ionization mass spectrometry (TIMS) for strontium isotopes, and secondary ion mass spectrometry (SIMS) for in situ carbon isotope composition. Additionally, laser ablation inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (LA-ICPMS) is used for in situ elemental analysis.

Enablement.Question: How does the selection of sample sites and preparation techniques impact the ability to study carbon isotope excursions during the PETM?
Enablement.Answer: The selection of sample sites, such as the Tingri and Gamba sections in south Tibet, and preparation techniques, like micro-drilling under a light microscope to obtain diagenetically less-altered micrites and LBF fragments, are crucial for studying carbon isotope excursions. These methods help ensure that the samples reflect the original geochemical conditions and enable the precise identification of the Paleocene/Eocene boundary.

Enablement.Question: What conditions or methodologies are necessary to distinguish between in situ and reworked larger benthic foraminifera in carbonate sections when studying the Paleocene-Eocene boundary?
Enablement.Answer: To distinguish between in situ and reworked larger benthic foraminifera, researchers must ensure that the studied sections comprise fully marine carbonate sediments and are complete on millennial time scales. This involves careful analysis of stratigraphic intervals and the use of carbon isotope data to confirm the preservation of carbonate sediments produced during the PETM.

Expectation.Question: Why might researchers expect challenges in obtaining complete marine carbonate sections when studying the Paleocene-Eocene thermal maximum (PETM)?
Expectation.Answer: Researchers might expect challenges in obtaining complete marine carbonate sections due to issues like non-marine sediments or reworked foraminifera, which can affect the stratigraphic intervals close to the Paleocene/Eocene boundary. These factors can hinder the accurate designation of the P/E boundary and understanding of larger benthic foraminifera (LBF) responses to the PETM.

Expectation.Question: What could be the reasons for expecting discrepancies in carbon isotope excursion (CIE) profiles when comparing different depositional environments?
Expectation.Answer: Discrepancies in CIE profiles might be expected when comparing different depositional environments because factors such as local diagenetic alterations, differing sedimentation rates, and varying nannoplankton vital effects can lead to variations in the recorded isotope values, thereby making inter-regional correlation challenging.

Expectation.Question: Why might researchers anticipate difficulties in using isotope data to reflect open surface ocean carbon cycling in shallow epicontinental seas?
Expectation.Answer: Researchers might anticipate difficulties because the isotope data from shallow epicontinental seas might be affected by regional geological processes or diagenetic alterations that can obscure the primary isotopic signals, making it challenging to extrapolate findings to represent carbon cycling in the open surface ocean.

Judgmental.Question: How do you evaluate the effectiveness of using isotopic composition analysis in carbonate sections to trace geochemical events such as the Paleocene-Eocene thermal maximum?
Judgmental.Answer: Isotopic composition analysis in carbonate sections is considered effective for tracing geochemical events like the Paleocene-Eocene thermal maximum. This method allows for the identification of carbon isotope excursions (CIE) which are indicative of massive carbon input into the atmosphere-ocean system. The method's reliability is enhanced by using well-preserved carbonate samples and comparing data with other global records.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, what are the potential benefits and limitations of using parallel limestone sections from different regions to study the carbon isotope excursion profile during the PETM?
Judgmental.Answer: The potential benefits of using parallel limestone sections include the ability to correlate data across different depositional environments and enhance the understanding of regional vs. global carbon cycle changes. Limitations might include regional variations that could obscure global trends and potential diagenetic effects that could alter isotopic signals.

Request/Directive.Question: Please describe the technological instruments and techniques used for measuring isotopic compositions and element concentrations in carbonate samples.
Request/Directive.Answer: The isotopic compositions of carbon and oxygen in carbonate samples were measured using a gas isotope ratio mass spectrometer (Finnigan MAT 251) at the University of Bremen. Strontium isotopes were analyzed through thermal ionization mass spectrometry (TIMS). The calcium carbonate content was determined using an acid dissolution method. In situ carbon isotope compositions were obtained via secondary ion mass spectrometry (SIMS), and elemental concentrations were measured using laser ablation inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (LA-ICPMS).
